head.title: When Antarctica Slips Into the Sea

hedline.hl1: When Antarctica Slips Into the Sea

abstract.p: Letter by environmental studies Professor Kai N Lee on David Helvarg's March 7 Op-Ed article; notes that while krill, at base of Antartica's food chain, are most abundant animal on earth in terms of total biomass, homo sapiens (common name 'people') is second most abundant species (S)

block.p: David Helvarg (Op-Ed, March 7) points out that krill -- tiny shrimplike creatures that are the base of Antarctica's food chain -- are the most abundant animal on earth in terms of total biomass. But he did not say that the second most abundant is homo sapiens (common name, ''people''). Both species weigh in at several hundred million tons.

David Helvarg (Op-Ed, March 7) points out that krill -- tiny shrimplike creatures that are the base of Antarctica's food chain -- are the most abundant animal on earth in terms of total biomass. But he did not say that the second most abundant is homo sapiens (common name, ''people''). Both species weigh in at several hundred million tons.

Human population grows. That, and the pressures we put on krill through fishing and unintended climate change, may enable us to claim the title of the most abundant species someday. Or we may come to appreciate, as Mr. Helvarg proposes, that a better way to look out for No. 2 may be to look out for No. 1.
KAI N. LEE Williamstown, Mass., March 8, 1999
The writer is a professor of environmental studies at Williams College.
